Award.AwardTitle: Summer Symposium in Real Analysis XXXVI
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to defray the expenses of participants in a week-long summer symposium on recent advances in real analysis that will be take place from July 25-30, 2012, at the Berks College campus of the Pennsylvania State University. Much of the funding will be directed toward the goal of disseminating knowledge to and the inclusion of underrepresented minorities and women mathematicians.

This conference is the thirty-sixth in a long-running series of real analysis summer symposia. The past decade has witnessed a resurgence, on both the national and international scenes, of research activity in the classical area of real analysis, a resurgence driven in part by the ever-growing importance of real analysis for many other mathematical disciplines. This trend is typified by the work of the three plenary speakers at the 2012 event: Zoltan Buczolich, Emma D'Aniello, and Yang Wang. The Summer Symposium, which throughout its existence has attracted a large international audience, will play a central role in future developments in the field. The conference will offer researchers the opportunity to hear and share the newest findings in the field of real analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for
the General Public 36thSummer Symposium in Real Analysis

From June 25-30, 2012, The Pennsylvania State University, Berks hosted the 36th Summer Symposium in Real Analysis. This conference has been held annually since 1978, twice in 1982, and is considered to be the premier conference of its type by members of the real analysis community. This year’s conference was particularly exciting and stimulated a great deal of new mathematical discussion.

We had top choices for each of our three plenary speaker slots and all accepted our invitation. Professor Zoltán Buczolich is from the prestigious Eötvös Lorand University in Hungary, and like our other plenary speakers is considered one of the very best research mathematicians in his area. He spoke on the topic of “Level set structure of real functions.” Professor Emma D’Aniello from the Seconda Università degli Studi di Napoli is a young dynamic research mathematician and has made significant research contributions to several branches of mathematics. Her lecture topic, “On topological chaos” attracted a good deal of attention and soon afterward, she and Professor Togo Nishiura began a successful collaboration, settling one open problem while still at the symposium. They are currently preparing their work for publication. Our last plenary speaker was Professor Yang Wang, Chair of the Department of Mathematics at Michigan State University and a renown scholar and speaker whose work bridges pure and applied areas. His talk, entitled “Peano curves for fractals” was brilliantly presented and also generated a great deal of discussion.

In addition to the plenary lectures, there were seventeen shorter talks by researchers from seven countries. The main audience for this series of symposia is the global community of real analysts. Real analysis as a discipline is the study of properties for functions defined on decimal numbers and is a continuation of the calculus classes taught throughout the mathematics curriculum. Research described at this symposium is derived from, has potential impact on and provides critical insight into Chaos Theory, Probability Theory, Theoretical Physics, and problems in engineering.

A detailed description of this symposium can be found at www.stolaf.edu/analysis
